title: In order to efficiently handle cycle detection, we consider each node as part of a tree. When adding an edge, we check if its two component nodes are part of distinct trees. Initially, each node makes up a one-node tree.

inline_content.Text: In order to efficiently handle cycle detection, we consider each node as part of a tree. When adding an edge, we check if its two component nodes are part of distinct trees. Initially, each node makes up a one-node tree.

title:
algorithm kruskalMST'(G: a graph)
    sort G's edges by their value
    MST = a forest of trees, initially each tree is a node in the graph
    for each edge e in G:
        if the root of the tree that e.first belongs to is not the same 
        as the root of the tree that e.second belongs to:
            connect one of the roots to the other, thus merging two trees
    
    return MST, which now a single-tree forest

content_resolved.code:
algorithm kruskalMST'(G: a graph)
    sort G's edges by their value
    MST = a forest of trees, initially each tree is a node in the graph
    for each edge e in G:
        if the root of the tree that e.first belongs to is not the same 
        as the root of the tree that e.second belongs to:
            connect one of the roots to the other, thus merging two trees
    
    return MST, which now a single-tree forest
